intro: Gilia sherman-hoytiae, commonly known as the Sherman-Hoyt's gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its slender, branched stems and clusters of small, delicate flowers that range in color from pink to red. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. It is part of the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is adapted to thrive in harsh, dry conditions. Gilia sherman-hoytiae plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
